claim.text: housing types that were common before 1940 and are now effectively illegal
claim.claim: Missing middle housing types (duplexes, triplexes, etc.) were common before 1940

results.summary: Unable to verify due to lack of web search permissions; however, this claim aligns with well-documented urban planning history.
results.detail: The claim that duplexes, triplexes, and similar housing types were common before 1940 and later restricted by zoning is a well-established thesis in urban planning literature, notably popularized by Daniel Parolek who coined 'missing middle housing.' Historical zoning, particularly single-family exclusionary zoning that spread after the 1926 Euclid v. Ambler Supreme Court case, did restrict these housing types in many jurisdictions. However, without web search access, I cannot verify specific statistics or sources to confirm the 1940 date and scope.

claim.text: Minneapolis eliminated single-family-only zoning in 2018, allowing triplexes on any residential lot
claim.claim: Minneapolis eliminated single-family-only zoning in 2018 and allowed triplexes on any residential lot

results.summary: Minneapolis adopted the Minneapolis 2040 plan in December 2018, but the triplex zoning changes were phased in and didn't fully take effect until 2020.
results.detail: The Minneapolis City Council approved the Minneapolis 2040 comprehensive plan in December 2018, which did eliminate single-family-only zoning citywide. However, the claim is slightly imprecise in two ways: (1) the plan was adopted in late 2018 but the zoning code amendments allowing triplexes were implemented in phases, with full effect in 2020; (2) the plan allows up to three units on lots previously zoned single-family, but with some size and lot coverage restrictions. The core claim about Minneapolis being the first major U.S. city to eliminate single-family zoning and allow multi-family on all residential lots is accurate.
sources: Unable to verify via web search - based on training knowledge. Minneapolis 2040 comprehensive plan documentation would be the primary source.

results.summary: Oregon passed House Bill 2001 in 2019, which legalized duplexes statewide on lots zoned for single-family housing.
results.detail: Oregon's HB 2001 was signed into law by Governor Kate Brown in August 2019. The law requires cities with populations over 10,000 to allow duplexes on any lot where single-family homes are permitted. Larger cities (over 25,000) must also allow additional middle housing types like triplexes, fourplexes, and cottage clusters. Oregon was the first state to enact such sweeping statewide zoning reform.
sources: Oregon Department of Land Conservation and Development Housing Choices program documentation

claim.text: California permitted lot-splitting and duplexes via SB 9 in 2022
claim.claim: California's SB 9 (2022) permitted lot-splitting and duplexes

results.summary: California SB 9 does permit lot-splitting and duplexes on single-family zoned lots, but it was signed in 2021 and took effect January 1, 2022.
results.detail: SB 9 (the California Housing Opportunity and More Efficiency Act, or HOME Act) was signed by Governor Gavin Newsom on September 16, 2021, and took effect on January 1, 2022. The law does allow lot splits (creating two parcels from one) and permits up to two housing units on parcels zoned for single-family residences. The claim is correct about what the law does but the bill was signed in 2021, though it did take effect in 2022.

claim.text: Sixteen to thirty units per acre, not sixty
claim.claim: Missing middle housing typically has density of 16-30 units per acre

results.summary: The range cited is reasonable for missing middle housing but the exact 16-30 units per acre figure may be one interpretation among several.
results.detail: Missing middle housing (duplexes, triplexes, courtyard apartments, etc.) does typically fall in a density range between single-family homes (4-8 units/acre) and mid-rise apartments (40+ units/acre). Common references cite ranges like 15-35 or 12-35 units per acre depending on the source and building type. The 16-30 range is within the general ballpark but specific bounds vary by source and municipality. Daniel Parolek, who coined the term 'missing middle housing,' generally describes these as moderate-density forms, though exact numeric ranges vary in practice.
sources: Unable to verify via web search - based on training knowledge about missing middle housing definitions
